article:
'Palestinian political violence' refers to acts of violence undertaken to
further the Palestinian cause. These political objectives include self-
determination in and sovereignty over Palestine, de Waart,
1994, [http://books.google.ca/books?um=1&lr=&q=%22armed+struggle%22+%22self-
determination%22+palestinian&btnG=Search+Books p. 223]. Referencing Article 9 of
The [[Palestinian National Charter]] of 1968. The Avalon Project has a copy here
[http://avalon.law.yale.edu/20th_century/plocov.asp] De
Waal, 2004, [http://books.google.ca/books?id=KQMSlAPqapkC&pg=PA29&dq=%22struggle+for+self-
determination%22+palestinian+violence&lr=#v=onepage&q=%22struggle%20for%20self-
determination%22%20palestinian%20violence&f=false pp. 29â30]. the
"liberation of Palestine" and establishment of a Palestinian state, either in
place of both Israel and the Palestinian territories, or solely in the
Palestinian territories. Schulz, 1999, [http://books.google-
.ca/books?id=YRkNAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA161&dq=%22liberation+of+Palestine%22+%22Palestin-
ian+state%22&lr=#v=onepage&q=%22liberation%20of%20Palestine%22%20%22Palestinian-
%20state%22&f=false p. 161]. Periodically directed toward more limited goals such
as the release of Palestinian prisoners, another key aim is to advance the
Palestinian right of return.

Palestinian groups involved in politically motivated violence include Hamas, the
Palestinian Liberation Organization (PLO), the Palestinian Islamic Jihad, Fatah,
the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine (PFLP), the Popular Front for
the Liberation of Palestine - General Command (PFLP-GC), the Democratic Front
for the Liberation of Palestine, and the Abu Nidal Organization. Tactics have included plane hijackings, stone throwing,
stabbing, shootings, and bombings. Beitler, Ruth Margolies. "The
intifada: Palestinian adaptation to Israeli counterinsurgency tactics" Terrorism
and Political Violence 7.2 (1995). Sep 5, 2010 Several of these groups are
considered terrorist organizations by the United States
government. [http://www.state.gov/j/ct/rls/other/des/123085.htm State Dept.
List of Terrorist organizations]

Palestinian political violence has targeted Israelis, Palestinians, Lebanese,
Jordanians, Egyptians Tuesday, October 26, 2004,
Interior Ministry: defendants are eight Egyptians led by a Palestinian national
living in Al-Arish [http://www.sis.gov.eg/en/Story.aspx?sid=21609] and
citizens of other countries. The attacks have taken place
within and outside Israel and have been directed at both military and civilian
targets. Israeli statistics state that 3,500 Israelis [http://old.btselem.org/statistics/english/Casualties.asp
B'Tselem â Statistics â Fatalities]. Btselem.org. Retrieved on 2012-05-
09. [http://www.mfa.gov.il/MFA/Terrorism-
+Obstacle+to+Peace/Palestinian+terror+before+2000/Which+Came+First-
+Terrorism+or+Occupation+-+Major.htm Which Came First â Terrorism or
"Occupation"? Israeli Ministry of Foreign Affairs] have been killed and
25,000 have been wounded as a result of Palestinian violence since the
establishment of the state of Israel in 1948. These figures include soldiers as
well as civilians, including those killed in exchanges of gunfire. [http://www.mfa.gov.il/MFA/MFAArchive/2000_2009/2000/1/Terrorism+deaths+in-
+Israel+-+1920-1999.htm Terrorism deaths in Israel â 1920â1999] [http://www.mfa.gov.il/MFA/Terrorism-
+Obstacle+to+Peace/Palestinian+terror+since+2000/Palestinian+violence+and+terro-
rism+since+September.htm Palestinian terrorism since Sept 2000]. Mfa.gov.il.
Retrieved on 2010-09-29.
headings: Palestinian groups involved in political violence
